      • addAnswerTime

        public void addAnswerTime(long answerTime)
        Adds a duration to the list of previous answer durations. Can be called directly with any chosen unit, or called by proxy via: 
        updateTimes(Date askedTime, Date answerTime)

        After adding to the list, this method then calculates the new value for averageResponseTimes.

        Parameters:
        answerTime - the answer time in seconds
        See Also:
        updateTimes(Date, Date)

      • updateTimes

        public void updateTimes(java.util.Date askedTime,
                        java.util.Date answerTime)
        Update lastAskedTime, lastAnswerTime, adds a duration element (in seconds' difference) to answerTimes, and updates averageResponseTime
        Parameters:
        askedTime - the time the question was asked, represented as a Date object
        answerTime - the time the question was answered, represented as a Date object

      • sumAnswerTimes

        public java.lang.Long sumAnswerTimes()
        Recursively calculate the average answer time (in seconds)
        Parameters:
        responseTimes - the answer times
        startIndex - the start index
        Returns:
        the sum of all the time durations within ArrayList<Long> answerTimes

      • setScore

        public java.lang.Double setScore(ScoreBy scoreBy,
                                 int multiplier)
        Calculates, sets, and returns a score using the ScoreBy's documented algorithm.
        Parameters:
        scoreBy - the ScoreBy object set as one of the enumerated values; each value has a documented algorithm.
        multiplier - the value to multiply by the algorithm's resulting value - which can be a number that is QUITE small.
        Returns:
        A double value that represents the score. If a multiplier of 1000 is passed in (my recommended value), then any player with a reasonable response time and correct ratio would receive a score between 100 and 1000, while a player with very poor performance may receive scores lower than 1. For example: 
         playerA.ratioCorrect = .98334;
 playerA.averageResponseTime = 2;
 -------------
 double score_A1 = playerA.setScore(ScoreBy.CORRECT_TO_TOTAL, 1000);
 score_A1 == 491.67
 
 double score_A2 = playerA.setScore(ScoreBy.CORRECT_TO_TOTAL, 100);
 score_A2 == 49.167
 
 double score_A3 = playerA.setScore(ScoreBy.CORRECT_TO_TOTAL, 0);
 score_A3 == .49167
 --------------------------
 
         playerB.ratioCorrect = .4658;
 playerB.averageResponseTime = 7;
 -------------
 double score = playerA.setScore(ScoreBy.CORRECT_TO_TOTAL, 1000);
 score == 66.5427906
 --------------------------
 
         playerC.ratioCorrect = 1;
 playerC.averageResponseTime = 19384;
 -------------
 double score = playerA.setScore(ScoreBy.CORRECT_TO_TOTAL, 1000);
 score == 0.0516
 --------------------------
        In order to select the right ScoreBy value, the following table provides a description of how each option calculates the score:
        ScoreBy Value Algorithm description Calculation (without multiplier)
        ScoreBy.CORRECT_TO_TOTAL The ratio of number of correct answers to the total number of answers submitted, as the base percentage as a value between 0 and 1. this.numCorrectAnswers / this.numQuestionsAnswered
        ScoreBy.RESPONSE_TIME_AVERAGE The average duration, in seconds, of the time between when a question is asked, and when the answer is submitted (whether correct or not). Questions NOT answered are NOT factored in. 1 / (this.averageResponseTime.getSeconds())
        ScoreBy.CORRECT_WEIGHTED_TIME This algorithm produces a score that is the percentage correct weighted by the inverse of the average response time. In other words, where the ratio of correct answers to total number of answers = r and the inverse of the average duration (in seconds) of response times = t, this score is calculated by multiplying r by t. (this.numberCorrect / this.numberAnswered) *
        (1 / this.averageResponseTime.getSeconds())
        If none of the scoring methods suit the purposes required, the setter function Stats.setScore(Double score) is available for any developer to write their own algorithm to calculate the score, and set it directly. Unlike this method, however, the Stats.setScore(Double score) does not return the value of the score.
        See Also:
        ScoreBy
